reviewerName: Bartok Kinski "A casual stroll through the lu...
reviewText: CLASS REUNION MASSACRE (1978) aka The Redeemer: Son of Satan! was not quite what I expected - I thought that this was going to be a Satanic slasher film but it was definitely more of a twisted religious film.Not a very convincing religious movie, be it considered slasher film OR Satanic horror. The story itself, is not very believable and is played out as if it were a typical slasher movie; six former students attend their tenth year class reunion and get murdered. The murders have something to do with a child (son of Satan?) who comes into sight out of an inland lake and a mysterious, zealot preacher.There is no suspense. There really aren't characters, only some that classify as religious archetypes. The biggest problem is that the movie is two things that directly counteract each other: religion vs Satan. You watch former students getting stabbed by a religious preacher.Being a lover of horror films and watching the good, the bad, and the just Really bad, it was comforting to watch a bizarre old 70's horror film.A mysteriously strange premise for a horror film, but not great execution. There are no twists, no surprises, and at the end of the film, you feel like the movie was more about seeing former students get killed than watching a religious Satanic story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A group of six old friends gather for their high school reunion, only to find themselves trapped, and at the mercy of an insane, vengeful preacher. THE REDEEMER: SON OF SATAN (aka: CLASS REUNION MASSACRE), is a decent enough slasher from that golden age of cinematic carnage, the 70s and 80s. The killer is interesting (he's a master of disguise doncha know!), the means of death are inventive, and the characters are wonderfully ridiculous! This one's more fun than a barrel full of razor blades and broken glass!... P.S.- The killer's disguises are the best aspect of the movie, especially his grim reaper and killer clown!...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having noticed this fillum on pre-order, I decided to watch my old copy of it to see if it was worth shelling out for the DVD, in short... 'NO'.Watching this made me wonder if some horror-fan fillum student had bribed the caretaker of their local college to let them make an amateur slasher on campus during the Summer holidays.Right from the beginning 'The Redeemer' is heavy-handed and clumsy with it's on-screen religious texts providing a tenuous excuse for some bowl-haired kid in bell-bottoms to walk out of a lake - allbeit in a quite well photographed & moody landscape shot. Obviously the child is the agent of redemption, no mystery there.Then we move onto a long, ham-fisted rant of a sermon, courtesy of hack-actor TG Finkbinder who is such a wild & cringeworthy parody of a fire & brimstone preacher that the killer could not possibly be anyone else in the cast.Six grossly exaggerated and wildly over-acted post-graduate examples of the Seven Deadly Sins [crikey, the director can't even count!] are then wheeled out one by one, and lured into the abandoned college by the most unconvincing of janitor imposters, ready to be bumped off one by one in some manner or other that doesn't even reference their apparent brand of sin - so no ironic justice then... No memorable death set-pieces either - the photography and execution is awful.For some reason a life-size clown puppet makes several appearances in this fillum and it is never explained whether the doll is being worked by an accomplice or whether the 'Wrath of God' extends to magically animating wooden figurines for fun & revenge.Just about the only twist was that this fillum is told in flashback - as TG Finkbinder rants in the pulpit he is alluding to acts of divine retribution he has already carried out. Quite why he needed an extra thumb to do that is anyone's guess.All in all, this fillum is an absolute hotch-potch mess,- no good as a serious stalk & slash effort, no good as a wry tongue in cheek horror. If you want 'poetic justice' and theatrical flair then watch Vincent Price in the glorious 'Theatre of Blood', if you want abandoned locations, gore and camp-acting-in-extremis go for Michele Soavi's deliciously well done 'Stagefright' instead.I'm giving 'The Redeemer' two stars only because there are a handful of far more dire 'one star' efforts out there.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: D. Steigman "Movie fan from silents to now"
reviewText: This movie is basically about a psycho killer priest who wears disguises & kills sinners who he recruited to a class reunion. He gets the ability to kill from an evil child. A lot of people compared this to the Omen because of the child that is involved in the film, but to me it reminded me more of the movie Frailty in terms of its religious message. Its not about a boy taking over ala Damien but of a person who wears some really creepy disguises to kill people who are sinners in (well in some cases) hideous ways all in the name of God.There are some pretty intense murder scenes in particular one in the ladies room. There is one terrific gore scene & some other cool things to recommend. The acting is ok, as is the story ..pretty simple - nothing that can easily be confusing if you follow it from start to finish. Some would say it isn't clear why these murders are happening to this group of people but if you read the text at the beginning & the end it is clear to a certain extent. There is a meaning to the killings. And he is killing those who have sinned.It is not a classic by any stretch of the imagination but it was a credible sincere effort. If you are a fan of films Crucible of Terror, Horror High , Horror Hospital and other low budget independent titles that companies like Code Red, Scorpion Releasing or Synapse Films would release , then Id recommend it easily.Dont expect too much and you'll be rewarded.Code Red released this with the disclaimer about not being the best transfer 'we did the best with the elements we found & released it due to popular demand" type of thingI found the transfer to be pretty viewable & despite the reel changes where it gets really grainy like something from Alpha Video, you can tell Code Red tried to make this as good as they could get. Id get this version over some of the other versions out there..So while this film isn't recommended for the general public who focus on mainstream titles like Avatar, Iron Man etc..this is for those who do have a passion for the independent low budget horror film fan. I was curious enough to buy it and was pleased with it..
summary: Pretty good film, not for everyone
Title: N/A

reviewText: Code Red does it again by finding a little-known 70's slasher film with religious overtones, giving it the proper restoration treatment and releasing it to unexpecting audiences. The Seven Deadly Sins were never deadlier, as a boy with two thumbs on one hand (!?!) helps kill the seven people responsible for making one man's life a living hell during his time in school. It all takes place at a class reunion, where each nasty person (each one representing the Seven Deadly Sins) is picked-off in various bloody ways. Looking for something different? Then look no further. First time on DVD!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of the most creepy and original horror films ever! Like Phantasm, you can tell this is the director's nightmare he made into a movie, especially when there's no explanation why things are happening. A priest gets possessed by a devil child in an elaborate plan to not only kill a handful of people but terrorize them over the weekend at a class reunion. If you like surprises in your horror, with this, you can't guess how the next scene will go down. The priest expresses his evil with several disguises from his own personal, insane bag of tricks. Well acted (especially by priest T.G. Finkbinder) by one hit wonder actors. The soundtrack matches the creepiness on screen and deserves credit for not letting you relax between kills. A very underrated flick. 16x9 and Windowboxed at 1.66:1 the picture and audio is grindhouse good.
Title: N/A
